Last night, I attended a candlelight vigil in Tulsa, honoring the victims of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre.

We must continue to uplift the stories of the survivors while shining a light on the impact of this tragic event. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E20IN7IX0AQnDAZ.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E20IN-mXMAYjddQ.jpg

This week, I'm joining my @TheBlackCaucus colleagues to bring attention to the Massacre and demand justice for survivors and their descendants.

Together, we honor the memory of Greenwood ‚Äî and we push for the equity and restorative justice that is long-overdue. (9/9)
The devastation of the Tulsa Race Massacre has been ignored and suppressed by official records, but it has never been forgotten by the Black community. (8/9)

100 years later, the Black community in Tulsa is still struggling from the damage of the Tulsa Race Massacre.

In 1920, Black and white residents had nearly identical homeownership rates. Today, white Tulsans are nearly twice as likely to own a home as Black Tulsans. (7/9)

The Tulsa Race Massacre crushed the center of Black wealth in America.

Over the next 100 years, the impact of the Massacre could be seen in lower net worth, educational attainment, and home ownership for Black families in Tulsa. (6/9)

In the wake of the Tulsa Race Massacre, at least 9,000 people were left homeless and penniless.

A 2001 state commission report detailed that residents claimed $1.8 million in property loss ‚Äî an equivalent of $27 million in today‚Äôs dollars ‚Äî for the damage done that night. (5/9)

The Tulsa Race Massacre resulted in as many as 300 deaths, and the destruction of thousands of homes and businesses.

More than 800 people were admitted to hospitals, and up to 6,000 Black residents were imprisoned, many for several days. Greenwood would never be the same. (4/9)

The night of May 31, a violent white mob descended on the Greenwood District, torching homes and businesses, brutally assaulting and killing anyone in their way, and looting what was left in the wake. (3/9)

Greenwood was a beacon of hope for Black Americans across the country. It was an example of what Black families could achieve, despite the segregation and bigotry of the time.

Then in roughly 48 hours, Greenwood was destroyed. (2/9)

100 years ago, the Greenwood District of Tulsa was the wealthiest Black community in America.

Known as "Black Wall Street", Greenwood was a bright and vibrant place where Black professionals and their families could flourish and build wealth. (1/9)

RT @RepHorsford The devastation of the Tulsa Race Massacre has been ignored and suppressed by official records, but it has never been forgotten by the Black community. (8/9)

RT @RepHorsford 100 years later, the Black community in Tulsa is still struggling from the damage of the Tulsa Race Massacre.

In 1920, Black and white residents had nearly identical homeownership rates. Today, white Tulsans are nearly twice as likely to own a home as Black Tulsans. (7/9)

RT @RepHorsford The Tulsa Race Massacre crushed the center of Black wealth in America.

Over the next 100 years, the impact of the Massacre could be seen in lower net worth, educational attainment, and home ownership for Black families in Tulsa. (6/9)

RT @RepHorsford In the wake of the Tulsa Race Massacre, at least 9,000 people were left homeless and penniless.

A 2001 state commission report detailed that residents claimed $1.8 million in property loss ‚Äî an equivalent of $27 million in today‚Äôs dollars ‚Äî for the damage done that night. (5/9)

RT @RepHorsford The Tulsa Race Massacre resulted in as many as 300 deaths, and the destruction of thousands of homes and businesses.

More than 800 people were admitted to hospitals, and up to 6,000 Black residents were imprisoned, many for several days. Greenwood would never be the same. (4/9)

As you learn, it‚Äôs important to remember that history isn‚Äôt just something in our past. There are still survivors from this massacre. We owe it to them, and to the generations that have and will come after, to understand why this happened and make sure it never does again. END

LISTEN: Today‚Äôs episode of The Daily outlines the events of 100 years ago and starts with the voice of a victim still alive today. https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/01/podcasts/the-daily/tulsa-race-massacre-centenary.html 13/14

WATCH: If you‚Äôre looking for something to watch, there are a number of documentaries on the topic, including a new one from PBS, to check out. Some really good options here: https://www.essence.com/entertainment/7-tulsa-race-massacre-documentaries-and-specials-to-watch/ 12/14

READ: There are a lot of good books on this topic ranging from the history of the community, to the attack, to the aftermath. The Oklahoman has a fantastic list here: https://www.oklahoman.com/story/lifestyle/2021/05/30/16-books-read-1921-tulsa-race-massacre/7451391002/ 11/14

EXPLORE: The @NYTimes has a great interactive piece from over the weekend where you can really explore the Greenwood neighborhood and get a feel for the scope of the impact of its destruction. https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2021/05/24/us/tulsa-race-massacre.html 10/14

A NEW SPARK: If we‚Äôre going to truly right these wrongs, then the spark that ignites action must be information and understanding. Today, I hope you‚Äôll join me in doing at least one thing to further understand this massacre. 9/14

PROGRESS: We can‚Äôt let this anniversary go by without a rededication to progress. That starts by recognizing that helping to right the wrongs of the past aren‚Äôt done at anyone‚Äôs expense, but failing to do so comes at all of our expense. 8/14

REFLECTION: We‚Äôve undoubtedly made progress over the past century, but the fuel for that hatred and violence hasn‚Äôt completely gone away. We still struggle with the concept of shared power - if I have something, it doesn‚Äôt come at your expense.This fuels racism and otherism. 7/14

COST: Hundreds were killed and millions in generational wealth was lost. Just as impactful is the psychological cost. We can only imagine the horror for Black Americans across the country to see a thriving community destroyed with no cause but their race. 6/14

TERROR: That hate wasn‚Äôt just a handful of misguided men. Some were deputized by authorities and given weapons. This wasn‚Äôt just done out of retribution, it was done to completely silence a community. 5/14

SPARK: A comprehensive report from 2001 explains that a false assault allegation against a Black teen was the catalyst for violence. But that spark only ignited something that went deeper: an idea that Black power and prosperity was zero-sum and needed to end. 4/14

SEPARATED: Business owners and working families prospered even though they were segregated from the rest of the community. Every day was a reminder that they were an ‚Äòother‚Äô - even those well-off in Greenwood couldn‚Äôt frequent businesses in White Tulsa. 3/14

PROSPERITY: The Greenwood area of Tulsa was a thriving Black community and often referred to as Black Wall Street. The residents succeeded against the odds, but their success was a model and a symbol for what could be. 2/14 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E2z78NIXMAgLRGI.jpg

100 years ago today, a thriving Black community in Tulsa was destroyed by a white mob driven by hate and anger. I never learned about this in school but it is a history we must confront. Now the lessons of the Tulsa Race Massacre are more important than ever. THREAD. #Tulsa100 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E2z7vHXXEAQEhPA.png
